DRAMATIS hamma—Thus although as it stands the dialogue is one continuous conversation with the same persons present throughout, it falls into two separate parts, in which two different speakers take the lead ; but the rejoinder in both cases is made by Cotta. Velleius the Epicurean speaker and Balbus the Stoic are only known to us from this book, except that De Oratore (iii. 78) gives Velleius as a friend of the orator L. Licinius Crassus, and mentions ‘ duo Balbi ' among the Stoics of the day. Both spokes- men, and also Cotta the Academic, are spoken of here as leaders in their schools (i. 16). Cotta had already been commended to Cicero by Atticus (Att. xiii. 19. 3), and had been mentioned by Cicero before in De Ora- tore (iii.145) as having joined the Academy ; Cicero
